T1059.001::[APT19] used PowerShell commands to execute payloads.
T1071.001::[APT19] used HTTP for C2 communications. [APT19] also used an HTTP malware variant to communicate over HTTP for C2.
T1132.001::An [APT19] HTTP malware variant used Base64 to encode communications to the C2 server.
T1204.002::[APT19] attempted to get users to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.
T1218.010::[APT19] used Regsvr32 to bypass application control techniques.
T1218.011::[APT19] configured its payload to inject into the rundll32.exe.
T1543.003::An [APT19] Port 22 malware variant registers itself as a service.
T1547.001::An [APT19] HTTP malware variant establishes persistence by setting the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Windows Debug Tools-%LOCALAPPDATA%\.
T1564.003::[APT19] used -W Hidden to conceal [PowerShell] windows by setting the WindowStyle parameter to hidden.
T1566.001::[APT19] sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments in RTF and XLSM formats to deliver initial exploits.
T1574.002::[APT19] launched an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant using a legitimate executable that loaded the malicious DLL.
T1588.002::[APT19] has obtained and used publicly-available tools like [Empire].
